explanations.summary: Vasoconstriction uses IP3 pathway: alpha-1 receptors → PLC → IP3 → Ca²⁺ release → contraction. cGMP and cAMP both cause RELAXATION (vasodilation), not constriction.

whyCorrect.d: IP3 (inositol trisphosphate) mediates vasoconstriction. Alpha-1 receptor activation → phospholipase C → IP3 production → Ca²⁺ release from SR → smooth muscle contraction.

whyIncorrect.a: cGMP ACTIVATION causes vasoDILATION (NO/nitric oxide pathway).
whyIncorrect.b: cAMP STIMULATION causes vasoDILATION (beta-2 receptor pathway).
whyIncorrect.c: cGMP STIMULATION causes vasoDILATION, not vasoconstriction.

explanations.summary: Increased cAMP in vascular smooth muscle causes RELAXATION. cAMP activates PKA → phosphorylates MLCK → decreased Ca²⁺ sensitivity → relaxation. cAMP does NOT activate NOS or cause contraction.

whyCorrect.b: Increased cAMP causes vascular smooth muscle RELAXATION. cAMP → PKA → phosphorylation of myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) → reduced Ca²⁺ sensitivity → relaxation/vasodilation.

whyIncorrect.a: NOS (nitric oxide synthase) is activated by Ca²⁺/calmodulin, not by cAMP.
whyIncorrect.c: The Na⁺/K⁺ pump is not directly activated by cAMP in this context.
whyIncorrect.d: Increased cAMP causes RELAXATION, not contraction. Contraction uses IP3/Ca²⁺ pathway.

explanations.summary: Vasoconstriction is mediated by IP3 signaling: alpha receptors → PLC → IP3 → Ca²⁺ release → contraction. cGMP, cAMP, and PGE2 generally cause vasodilation.

whyCorrect.d: IP3 (inositol trisphosphate) mediates vasoconstriction. Gq-coupled receptors (alpha-1) activate PLC → IP3 → releases Ca²⁺ from SR → smooth muscle contracts.

whyIncorrect.a: cGMP stimulation causes vasoDILATION via NO pathway, not vasoconstriction.
whyIncorrect.b: PGE2 generally causes vasodilation (though effects vary by receptor subtype and vascular bed).
whyIncorrect.c: cAMP stimulation causes vasoDILATION via beta receptor pathway.
